objtitle.title: *The Last Supper: "Verily I say unto You that One of You Shall Betray Me"*

objdescid.compdate: 1799The work was exhibited at the Royal Academy in 1799.

objinfo.medium: water-based tempera with a glue and/or gum binder and with pen and ink outlining

provenance.name: National Gallery of Art, Washington
provenance.note: Acquired, and probably commissioned, from Blake by Thomas Butts, c. 1799; by inheritance in 1845 to Thomas Butts, Jr.; sold from his collection, Foster and Son auction, London, 29 June 1853, lot 87 (with lots 85 and 86, *Christ Giving Sight to Bartimaeus*, Butlin 420, and *Job and His Daughters*, Butlin 394, for 11s. to John Clark Strange); possibly an anonymous collector or collectors; the dealer B. F. Stevens and Brown; sold anonymously, Christie's, 22 July 1949 (£819 to the William Blake Trust); sold to Lessing J. Rosenwald in 1951 for presentation to the National Gallery of Art, Washington.

repository.addressline: Constitution Avenue NW, between 3rd and 9th Streets
Mailing Address: 2000B South Club Drive, Landover, Maryland 20785

desc.objtitle: The Last Supper: "Verily I Say Unto You That One of You Shall Betray Me", Object 1 (Butlin 424)

objnote.p: Blake signed the work with his monogram, lower left; see the textual transcription. An enhanced image of the monogram has been provided below. He exhibited the work at the Royal Academy in 1799. The painting was restored by John Hell in 1949-51.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This design illustrates the Last Supper (Matthew 26:20-34). Jesus and his twelve apostles sit in a darkened, shadowy room on carpets that are rolled to provide cushions. In the center of the group are (left to right) a goblet, a pitcher with a loaf of bread below it, another goblet, a plate with three loaves of bread and an empty plate above it, and a third goblet. Jesus sits at the head of the group, facing forward and leaning on a roll of carpet with his left arm. He wears a gown, and has long hair, a beard, and a halo composed of beams of light. His legs are stretched out to the left. His arms are bent upward, with his palms out and his fingers outspread. To the left of Jesus sit four apostles. The leftmost apostle sits, facing away but with his head turned to the right, perhaps to look at Jesus. He wears a gown like a toga, and has curly hair and a beard. His legs are bent under him so that he sits on them. His arms are bent upward, with his palms out and his fingers spread, as if in imitation of Jesus's gesture. The second apostle from the left in this group sits facing forward, but looking up and to his right. He appears to be an old man with long hair and a beard. He also wears a gown and has his arms raised, with his hands together as if in prayer. The apostle second from the right has long hair and sits, facing forward but looking to the right and down, with his left arm leaning on a carpet roll. His arms are raised, with his hands clasped together, as if in prayer. He wears a gown. The rightmost apostle in this group sits, facing forward, but looking to the right. He wears a gown and has curly hair and a beard. His arms are bent with his hands together, as if in prayer. To the right of Jesus sit four apostles. The leftmost apostle, though presumably a male, is very feminine looking. This may be John, the youngest of the Evangelists. He has long, curly hair, wears a gown, and sits facing forward and looking to the left, presumably at Jesus. Like Jesus, his legs are extended out, though this apostle's are to the right. His arms are crossed with his hands on his chest, finger's slightly spread. The next apostle to the right sits, facing left, and presumably looking at Jesus. His right arm is raised, with his hand at his face, palm vertical, perhaps in a gesture of surprise or an attempt to shield his face. He has curly hair and a beard. The next apostle to the right in this group sits, facing forward but looking to the left. He has curly hair and wears a gown. He leans with his right arm on a carpet roll with his right hand on his breast. His left arm is bent with the palm out and fingers spread. This gesture suggests that the man is indicating that he is not the one who will betray Christ. The rightmost apostle in this group sits, or perhaps kneels, facing left. He has a beard and his shoulders are hunched, as his head faces down. His arms are raised, with his hands together as if in prayer or supplication. In the foreground is a third group of four apostles. The leftmost apostle appears to be lying, facing away and to the right. He wears a gown and his body is slightly twisted. He has slightly curly hair and a beard, and his arms are bent with his hands together, as if in prayer or supplication. The next apostle to the right sits, facing away, with his legs extended to the left. He is partly clothed by a cloth or drapery around his waist. He faces right to look at the apostle to his right, and has his mouth open. He may be speaking. He also leans with his right arm on a carpet roll. The apostle second from the right in this group sits, facing away but looking to the apostle on the left. He has long curly hair and wears a gown like a toga. His left arm is raised, with the palm vertical and fingers spread. His legs are outstretched to the right. His mouth is slightly open; he may be speaking. The rightmost apostle of this group sits, facing forward, with his legs outstretched to the right. He leans with his right arm on a carpet roll. His left arm is bent, with the palm up and fingers spread to hold coins. He seems to point to his left palm with his right index finger to count the coins. There may be a purse dangling from his right wrist. This is Judas, Christ's betrayer (although in the Bible he will not receive payment until after the betrayal). He has long hair and a beard and is probably looking at the coins.

component.illusobjdesc: Jesus and his twelve apostles sit in a darkened, shadowy room.

Jesus and his twelve apostles sit on carpets that are rolled to provide cushions. In the center of the group are (left to right) a goblet, a pitcher with a loaf of bread below it, another goblet, a plate with three loaves of bread and an empty plate above it, and a third goblet. These all appear to be on the floor of the room.

Jesus sits at the head of the group, facing forward and leaning on a roll of carpet with his left arm. He wears a gown, and has long hair, a beard, and a halo composed of beams of light. His legs are stretched out to the left. His arms are bent upward, with his palms out and his fingers outspread.

To the left of Jesus sit four apostles. The leftmost apostle sits, facing away but with his head turned to the right, perhaps to look at Jesus. He wears a gown like a toga, and has curly hair and a beard. His legs are bent under him so that he sits on them. His arms are bent upward, with his palms out and his fingers spread, as if in imitation of Jesus's gesture.

To the left of Jesus sit four apostles. The apostle second from the left sits facing forward, but looking up and to his right. He appears to be an old man with long hair and a beard. He also wears a gown and has his arms raised, with his hands together as if in prayer or supplication.

To the left of Jesus sit four apostles. The apostle second from the right in this group has long hair and sits, facing forward but looking to the right and down, with his left arm leaning on a carpet roll. His arms are raised, with his hands clasped together, as if in prayer or supplication. He wears a gown.

To the left of Jesus sit four apostles. The rightmost apostle in this group sits, facing forward, but looking to the right. He wears a gown and has curly hair and a beard. His arms are bent and his hands together, as if in prayer or supplication.

To the right of Jesus sit four apostles. The leftmost apostle, though presumably a male, is very feminine looking. He may be John, the youngest of the Evangelists. He has long, curly hair, wears a gown, and sits facing forward and looking to the left, presumably at Jesus. Like Jesus, his legs are extended out, though this apostle's are to the right. His arms are crossed with his hands on his chest, fingers slightly spread. He leans with his right arm on a carpet roll.

To the right of Jesus sit four apostles. The apostle second from the left sits, facing left, and presumably looking at Jesus. His arm is raised, with his hand at his face, palm vertical and fingers slightly spread, perhaps in a gesture of surprise or an attempt to shield his face. He has curly hair and a beard.

To the right of Jesus sit four apostles. The apostle second from the right in this group sits, facing forward but looking to the left. He has curly hair and wears a gown. He leans with his right arm on a carpet roll. His right arm is bent over his chest with his right hand, fingers slightly spread, on his breast. His left arm is bent with the palm vertical and fingers spread. These gestures suggest that he is indicating that he is not the apostle who will betray Christ.

To he right of Jesus sit four apostles. The rightmost apostle in this group sits, or perhaps kneels, facing left. He has a beard and his shoulders are hunched, as his head faces down. His arms are raised, with his hands together as if in prayer or supplication.

In the foreground is a third group of four apostles. The leftmost apostle appears to be lying, facing away and to the right. He wears a gown and his body is slightly twisted. He has slightly curly hair and a beard, and his arms are bent with his hands together, as if in prayer or supplication.

In the foreground is a third group of four apostles. The apostle second from the left sits, facing away, with his legs extended to the left. He is partly clothed by a cloth or drapery around his waist. He faces right at the apostle to his right, and has his mouth open. He may be speaking. He also leans with his right arm on a carpet roll.

In the foreground is a third group of four apostles. The apostle second from the right sits, facing away but looking to the apostle on his left. He has long curly hair and wears a gown like a toga. His left arm is raised, with the palm vertical and fingers spread. His mouth is slightly open; he may be speaking. His legs are outstretched to the right.

In the foreground is a third group of four apostles. The rightmost apostle in this group sits, facing forward, with his legs outstretched to the right. He leans with his right arm on a carpet roll. His left arm is bent, with the palm up and fingers spread to hold coins. He seems to point to his left palm with his right index finger to count the coins. There may be a purse dangling from his right wrist. This is Judas, Christ's betrayer (although in the Bible he will not receive payment until after the betrayal). He has long hair and a beard and may be looking at the coins.

lg.l: invThe upper parts of the letters are obscured, possibly by paint added during restoration.
